Perry: The British Tennis Pioneer

05/08/2013

After a wonderful summer for British tennis, Jamie Summers looks back at the working class roots of Britain's first tennis ace, Fred Perry

Image by

By undefined undefined

British Tennis is on a high at the moment. Laura Robson continues to get stronger event by event in the women's game, and on the men's side of things, Andy Murray needs no introductions at all. Last year, the Scot suffered an agonising Wimbledon final defeat at the hands of Roger Federer. But after winning Olympic Gold and following that up by winning his first Grand Slam in November, 2013 was the year that it finally happened. Andy Murray became the first Brit since Fred Perry back in 1936 to win the men's title at Wimbledon. Before Murray's win, Perry had become renowned as the last British man to experience the sweet taste of victory at the All-England Club - but who exactly was he? Frederick John Perry was born in Stockport, Cheshire, in 1909. His father was a cotton-spinner in the area and shortly after Perry's ninth birthday, he became national secretary of the Co-Operative Party - the center-left party associated with Labour. Samuel Perry later became Co-Operative MP for Kettering and the family moved to Ealing, East London. Perry's first wins came at the World Table Tennis Championships in 1928/29, being renowned for his speed and technique. Subsequently bursting into the main form of the game, Perry had to overcome major social barriers in order to gain success on the main stage. Tennis in 1930s Britain was a quintessentially Southern, middle-class sport; one dominated by those able to afford the luxury of their own lawn to practice. That was in stark contrast to the working class Northern background from which Perry hailed. Nevertheless, it was perhaps this difference, the 'new kid on the block' tag, which benefited Perry in his game. He won his first major tennis championship when he won the US Open in 1933, making him the top amateur player in the world. This was followed up with another US Open title in 1934, along with the Australian and Wimbledon titles. Perry's first and only French Open title came in 1935, and he secured his second Wimbledon title in the summer of the same year. He then won Wimbledon for the third and final time in 1936, whilst also adding another US Open title to his vast collection of trophies. Recently, Perry's final victory at Wimbledon has become recognised simply for being the last time a British man was victorious. Nevertheless, at the time it made waves in its own right. Perry had defeated his opponent, Gottfried von Cramm - a German aristocrat - in straight sets. In addition, Perry had swept up and concluded the game in less than three--quarters of an hour. That made the match by far the shortest of the Twentieth Century, and indeed the second-shortest of all time. It wasn't until after his third Wimbledon title in 1936 that Perry actually turned professional, a move which alienated him from the high social circles of the contemporary British game. He achieved little of any note in the remainder of his career. Nevertheless, Perry had won the hearts of the Wimbledon crowds with his third successive victory in 1936. It was not only the manner in which he defeated his opponent, but the fact that a working class man had done so, which inspired so many of the 1930s crowd. Perry had initially been unwelcome at Wimbledon, receiving a cold reception from those in the game. However, within 2 short years, he had won their affections. This was a man that had quite simply achieved wonders in tennis, despite the difference in background between Perry and those around him. His sporting success led to Perry becoming a leading eligible bachelor, and in a time where the press was increasingly gaining strength, his personal life gained almost as much attention across the world as his triumphs on the court. Perry made headlines in 1934 for his romantic involvement with German actress and singer Marlene Dietrich. This was followed up with his engagement to British actress Mary Lawson. Perry eventually went on to marry four times; he remained married to his fourth wife until his death. After leading a high-profile life and enjoying a massively successful career in the game, Perry's tale ended sadly. He eventually died in 1995, aged 85, after breaking his ribs whilst in Australia. Fred Perry's legacy is clear; he is remembered by many as one of the greatest tennis players of all time. Although he has been criticised by some for not doing more for the game, his impressive record speaks for itself, with eight Grand Slam titles including three on SW19. These all pre-dated the tennis Open Era which began in 1968. A statue of Perry was erected in 1984 at the All England Club to mark the 50th anniversary of his first victory at Wimbledon, acting as an enduring reminder of his achievements. He also still has a successful clothing brand to his name, which was until recently worn by Andy Murray. He is also honoured in his home town, lending his name to the 'Fred Perry Way' walking route. The house of his birth is adorned with a blue plaque of historical significance and Local Government offices are also based in a building carrying the name 'Fred Perry House'. At the height of his game, Fred Perry managed to defy the odds. From his modest North Cheshire beginnings, he arrived uninvited into a social elite and gained the affections of the tennis world, demonstrating that sportspeople could and should achieve success on the basis of determination and ability alone. It is perhaps for this reason that he is most remembered as a pioneering icon of British tennis. Perry's triumphs weighed heavily upon the shoulders of British tennis players for nearly 80 years. Although Virginia Wade brought success to the women's game by winning Wimbledon in 1977, no British males were able to replicate Perry until Andy Murray did so this Summer. In the wake of the London Olympics last year, tennis came under criticism as one of the most underachieving sports in Britain. Despite colossal amounts of funding over recent years, tennis has consistently failed to deliver on the big stage. However, perhaps now the tide is turning. Under Ivan Lendl's guidance, Murray has come on leaps and bounds. His astonishing straight-set crushing of Novak Djokovic signalled a new era for world tennis. Amongst simply remarkable players such as Djokovic, Nadal and Federer, Murray has a realistic chance of becoming the best player in the world. Murray's success has led to an increased interest across the UK in tennis amongst people of all ages and abilities. Lord Coe stated in 2012 that the aim of the Olympics in London was to 'inspire a generation' of sportsmen and women. In the 1930s, Fred Perry left a legacy having captured people's hearts and inspiring them to realise their ambition. Hopefully, Andy Murray can now do the same and become the next legacy maker of the British game.
